column4: ok, so perhaps: 25GB (NTFS) for windows, 10GB (ext3) for Ububtu, 100GB (fat32) for media, 40GB (NTFS) for windows application, 25GB (ext3) for Ubuntu applications.  Total 200GB.
what doyou think?
if you mostly use linux, consider using ext3 for your media partition and loading an ext3 driver in windows.
you don't need 25GB for apps ... I have 7.5 GB for apps and that is just barely halffull (and I have most things installed twice! 32/64 bits)
and that includes all of the system apps.
Why don't you try 15 GB for windows, 40 GB for your warez, 10 GB for /, 15 GB for /home and the rest for media.
it is very possible, just not efficient :)
why is itnot efficient?
applications in Linux don't eat up harddrive in the same way as windows so devoting a large amount of space to them is impratical (unless you're running special CAD software or some such)
yep.  Although fat32 is pretty lame ... ext3 with ext3 drivers for windows or NTFS support in Linux is nicer ... but those both take some special loving.  So go with fat32 your first time.
ok, now for the dumb questions.  why do you say 10g for / and 15g for /home?  what does this mean? alternatively, where should I go to find out?
/ will be where all of your system configuration and program files go.  And where your logs and such are.  /home is where your personal configuration and files will be.
don't forget 1 GB for swap space (that is what Linux uses when it runs out of RAM).
do you have a blank disk now?  It is easier to install windows first and Linux second.  You can create empty partitions in the windows install and then format them during the Linux install.
you should probably put the partitions in the right order, something like C:, /, swap, extended(D:, /home, media)
you are saying I must create the partitions is a specific order?
no, but there are limitations.  If you put / too far back on the disk grub won't work (atleast older versions wouldn't, I haven't tried with the latest and greatest).
don't paste them to their own lines ...
that should work happily.  How much RAM do you have?
that is the easiest way.  You should probably make a 1GB partition for "swap" too.
no, you format it as swap (instead of ext3, fat, etc)
